 180: 
 181: # Notes
 182: # 1. The get_point_var() is incorrectly implemented for the time being as I was unable to
 183: #    understand how to calculate point-wise variance. In the paper, it is made clear that
 184: #    each point has a weight and that "The weights can be chosen as the inverses of the
 185: #    variances giving most weight to data points with low variability". The old
 186: #    implementation of get_point_var() finds the variance of the x value and the variance
 187: #    of the y value. It returns the average of these two variances. I don't believe this
 188: #    worked correctly. The current implementation simply returns 1 (i.e. point wise
 189: #    variance is not computed).
 190: # 2. Currently get_sample_vars() is unused since only the variance of each point is neeeded
 191: #    and I'm unsure if the variance of a point is related to the sample variances.
 192: # 3. Investigate faster way to calculate b (intercept), perhaps using the gradient, rho and
 193: #    other values calcualted and relating to polar coordinates. I may have already fixed
 194: #    this. I'm going through today and tidying notes which may or may not be out of date,
 195: #    whoops.
 196: # 4. tan_2_alpha = numerator / denominator will encounter a division by zero error if the
 197: #    points forming the line are EXACTLY linear. However, this is practically impossible.
 198: # 5. get_theta(x, y) attempts to solve a division by zero error by setting x to be the max
 199: #    system value if it is equal to 0. This patch did not work for tan_2_alpha.
 200: # 6. Investigate all places that involve division and explore edge cases that may lead to
 201: #    division by zero errors (like the above).
 202: # 7. Review method for identifying sign of gradient. If first or last point is an outlier, the
 203: #    current method will be unreliable. Perhaps use the average change in height between the points.
 204: #    If the average change is negative, then the gradient should be made negative and vice versa.
 205: #    Additionally, the average change could also exclude one point at a time and observer how much
 206: #    the average changes (to identify and remove outliers). However, this is likely unecessary and
 207: #    too computationally expensive (especially when our goal is near real-time performance). Pretty
 208: #    sure this comment has been fixed as I have gotten the algorithm correctly working.
 209: # 8. Look at any places that use len(x) and see if this can be turned into a parsed constant that
 210: #    doesn't need to be repeatedly re-calculated.
